conclusion: Analyze the motion of the dipole in the presence of a magnetic field.
The dipole consists of two charges, +q and -q, connected by a rigid rod of length d.
The magnetic field B is perpendicular to the plane of the dipole, which is the XY-plane.
The dipole is aligned with the X-axis and has an initial angular velocity ω0 in the XY-plane.
Its center of mass is at the origin with an initial velocity v0 parallel to the XY-plane.
The magnetic force on a moving charge q in a magnetic field B is given by F = q(v × B).
For the charge +q, the velocity due to the rotation is v+ = ω × r+, where r+ = d/2 i.
For the charge -q, the velocity is v- = ω × r-, where r- = -d/2 i.
The torque τ on the dipole due to the magnetic forces is given by τ = r+ × F+ + r- × F-.
The forces F+ and F- are perpendicular to r+ and r-, respectively, and have magnitudes qv+B and qv-B.
The net torque is τ = qd²ωB/2.
This torque will cause an angular acceleration α given by τ = Iα, where I = md²/2 is the moment of inertia of the dipole about its center of mass.
The angular acceleration is α = qd²ωB/md² = qBω/m.
The angular velocity ω changes with time according to ω(t) = ω0 - αt.
For the dipole to reverse its orientation, it must rotate through π radians.
The time t taken to reverse is when θ(t) = π, where θ(t) = ω0t - 1/2αt².
Set θ(t) = π, giving ω0t - 1/2αt² = π.
Substitute α = qBω0/m and solve for t.
The minimal ω0 occurs when ω(t) = 0 at t = t_reverse.
From ω(t) = ω0 - αt = 0, solve for t = mω0/qB.
